title: Combining Experiment and Theory To Unravel the Mechanism of Two-Electron Oxygen Reduction at a Selective and Active Co-catalyst

reactions.text: The 4e– ORR is the reaction that generally limits fuel cell efficiency while the 2e– ORR provides an electrochemical path for production of hydrogen peroxide, an important industrial chemical. Since an energy intensive centralized anthraquinone oxidation process now produces H2O2, there has been much recent interest in finding a simple decentralized electrochemical synthesis of H2O2 that could allow small-scale local production for applications such as cleaning of local water supplies.

Once OOH* exists, it can undergo a proton–electron transfer to form H2O2 (pH < 11.7) or an electron transfer to form HO2– (pH > 11.7) as determined by the pKa of H2O2 and given in eqs 0 and 1. Here, ΔG100 = −1.22 eV is obtained by combining the free energies of OOH* (eq 13 in the SI) and H2O2(aq) (from eq ), with a common H2O reference.
